subject: Guard requirements and design on BMC
commitMessage:
Guard requirements and design on BMC

This documents explains the guard management and requirements
on BMC.

Signed-off-by: Dhruvaraj Subhashchandran <dhruvaraj@in.ibm.com>
Change-Id: I82459b03f22cf2f873c3b56b77837969fbb12884

comments.message:
Patch Set 1:

This change is ready for review.

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

I strongly suggest cleaning this up from all the OpenPOWER references.  If this is going to be a POWER-specific, why is this in an openbmc/docs?

Patch Set 4:

This change is ready for review.
Uploaded patch set 5: New patch set was added with same tree, parent, and commit message as Patch Set 4.

Patch Set 5:

(11 comments)

document name need to change guard-xx
Patch Set 8: Published edit on patch set 7.

Patch Set 8:

(3 comments)

Can you please wrap lines at 80 chars? The document has a mix of wrapped and unwrapped lines and trailing whitespace.

Patch Set 8:

(2 comments)

> Patch Set 8:
> 
> (3 comments)
> 
> Can you please wrap lines at 80 chars? The document has a mix of wrapped and unwrapped lines and trailing whitespace.

Fixing the wrapped lines

Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

Been a few weeks with no response to review comments.

Patch Set 8:

> Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1
> 
> Been a few weeks with no response to review comments.

Working on a redesign based on the comments and the redfish interfaces, will push the new document
Patch Set 9: Published edit on patch set 8.
Patch Set 10: Published edit on patch set 9.
Patch Set 12: Published edit on patch set 11.
Patch Set 13: Published edit on patch set 12.
Patch Set 14: Published edit on patch set 13.
Patch Set 15: Published edit on patch set 14.
Patch Set 17: Published edit on patch set 16.
Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as f1640aa16a099efea3087cd1a33d7c4ca2c06522 by Patrick Williams
This is already mentioned in the starting of sentence

host creates gard records based on PEL? 

not clear on what basis gard records are created?

It is in the usecases, the gard records will be created when there is call from the error log or similar components, whether to create a gard or not in a situation is beyond the scope of this document.
how does the host know about repaired units
That is beyond the scope of this document
do we have anything in redfish schema to support this?
how is unit id defined? if it FRU id and what traslation need to be done
what mechanism is used by the host to create gard records is not captured
where are the gard records stored? are they restored during reboot? and how host is going to access this file? Does the gard manager listen to the PELS created and parse the gard records?

This is a true statement for all modern processors of all architectures, not just OpenPower.  Is there any strong reason to even reference OpenPower in this document at all?  Can't the design and code be common across all architectures?
How did we make this mistake after creat(2) was a thing?
It comes from the early FSP days when all "components" were required to be exactly 4 letters long.  Can we please fix this in the open source world?
i heard it was because the person that invented it didn't know how to spell.
Do gard-able entities have a 1-to-1 mapping with FRUs?
No, the chips, units or chiplets inside a FRU also can be gard-able

is there going to be a D-Bus object for each entry already, with its properties available to read?  If so, you probably don't need a list as one can just do a GetManagedObjects, GetSubTree, etc.

I would probably prefer that, as I believe there is a requirement that our PEL error logs cannot be deleted by anyone if its ID is in a gard record, so on every delete I have to check gard status, and having it on d-bus allows me to just be kept up to date by watching propertieschanges, ifaces added, etc
I think this needs a lot more exploration. Currently GARD records are stored as a binary blob in the GARD FFS partition. How is the BMC meant to handle this?
It is in the diagram, will add little more text
This seems overly complex. Why is inotify involved?
to indicate a change in the gard record file.
Can you please talk about the differences to the BMC case?
Guard record delete/create support is allowed only at BMC standby?
is this lab only use case?
a field engineer also should be able to use this option to isolate and test
This implies there is some correlation between the guard manager and the host state.  How do you handle multi-host systems?
The storage is owned by the host, so before updating the records BMC can check whether the respective host is up or not
The BMC will never clear records on its own?
BMC can clear records only if it can detect a repair action. I will reword this statement to indicate that.
Can we get someone from BMCweb to review this (Gunnar maybe)?

What is a "UnitID"?  I don't see this terminology in phosphor-dbus-interfaces at all.

Shouldn't this be a dbus object path pointing to some Inventory/FRU object?
Yes in the DBus will change this to a pointer to the unit

Can we use real options for these?  Shortening to 2 letters (get-guard) isn't very standard for Linux utilities.

You could consider making these like 'git <subcommand>'/'systemctl <subcommand>' style as well:

guard create --id=<id>
guard delete --id=<id>
guard clear
guard list
Just followed an existing implementation, this can be updated.
I need to know if an error ID has an outstanding guard record.  So I would just get all the objects that have the Guard interface and search those for my error ID?
yes you can get the list of all gard records, but for an openpower application it can use api provided by the gard library instead of Dbus interface.
Commandline arguments that aren't optional shouldn't have options.

Please fill this out. Your document states the the host owns the guard records - how does it create them? How does it retrieve them? How do the answers to these impact the BMC infrastructure? What trade-offs do we need to make? How might someone implement the infrastructure and what effects does the answer have on this proposal?
What new components are needed? How does a system integrator enable the guard infrastructure? What existing applications need to be modified? Are there any security impacts?
This sounds like manual testing. How are you planning to automate it? What about unit tests for affected codebases?
Yes these are manual test cases
Why manual? Why are there no automated tests? How do you expect to manage regressions in the code? What risks exist from a lack of automated test coverage and how are you going to mitigate them?
It will be good to group BMC application level uses case ( create/read) and Commandline requirements separately.

Since this design is restricting all guard records to being host created and host oriented (it seems like you're not covering fans and power supplies for example with this design), why is the BMC involved at all?  Why can't this be covered by the "Remote BIOS Configuration" design document that is also in flight: https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/docs/+/29320

Why aren't we covering BMC-centric hardware elements with this design?
BMC centric also in plan but not the immediate requirement, guarding anything in BMC also works in the same way except the guard records will be stored in the BMC itself.
I dont think they are separate
Can we add a mention to future design including the BMC then?

right, these documents should adhere to RFC2119

https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2119

I don't think this sentence is correct anyhow because you want the host to be able to create records, which contradicts the requirement that they not be altered while the host is running.

It seems like the requirement is that the "information given to the host is consistent for the duration of that host's execution", right?  Is there a reason to not hold a current/pending view of the records, so a user to issue a clear while the host is running but it doesn't take effect until the next reboot?

BIOS settings have a similar requirement.
The requirement is, if a common data store is used the BMC must not be altering the records while host is running, changing this statement since it is very implementation specific.
This is already documented in line 42.
This is about a single record.
am refering these two requirements. "Create a record in the guard records owned by the host,"  and "- An option should be given to the user to create or delete a guard record."
how id different from line 43 requirements?
This is about clearing all guard records, earlier one is about a single record.
for a subset of repaired units
Need More details on this .add "POWER specific " use case example.
This is an arbitrary id to the HW unit, not adding a power specific example.
Is this ID is p[art BMC some where or Host specific?
Need more details, like list of component name.
A human-readable name, it is self-explanatory.
Better to mention harwdware component name instead of component name.
I didnt list because that more implementation specific
In what way are they implementation-specific?
serial number plus part number, serial is not guaranteed unique on its own
This is what displayed to the user, changing to serial number and partnumber
Planned for June, removing this and planning it as a separate document for DMTF approval
Include design direction and scope of the Gurad Manager.
How user can get Error ID information? Example in Line 144 shows error ID. is it missing here?
That is not an id but a link to the error object in the case of gard manager.
Be consistent on the ID naming convention.  How it is diffrent from UnitID or ID mentioned in the line 115
Id is the id of the record, changing to unit id.
That is the list of guard records and the format is implementation-specific.
Include details, like How the user knows this ID?
Getting the common id of the hardware component is implementation-specific

Trailing whitespace, but I feel like this all should be part of the problem statement. I don't think it really describes an alternative that needs considering. I asked a series of questions on PS6 to prompt thoughts about what alternatives might exist and thus explanations of why we shouldn't adopt them.
What does this look like in concrete terms?
The guard records will be presented as part of logging.
Can you expand on this? How does this work? Presumably via Redfish? Are these OEM Redfish interfaces or is there something standard that we can use?

Please flesh this out to paragraphs not bullet points, and talk about testing methodology (manual vs automated), the risks we mitigate by adopting these and what risks might exist in spite of these tests (and how we should mitigate them).
Added general details here, adding more details into implementation specific document
Can you be sure to fix the word-wrapping in this revision?  It doesn't look like you updated that with the changes you made and there are now lots of 80+ character lines and awkward line changes.

FWIW you can use the `fold` commandline tool to do this for you, and it defaults to 80 chars.

https://linux.die.net/man/1/fold

This still doesn't feel optimal from a user-interface perspective.  It seems like the BMC should track deferred changes that cannot be applied while the host is running.

Can we at least list this as an alternative and/or future enhancement?
Manual clearing is possible but this is about automatic clearing of gard

Again, shouldn't this be inventory-oriented?  Otherwise, I agree with Jayanth that it is Power-specific.

If there is a translation between inventory items and host firmware requirements, that should be done in the IPMI/PLDM providers for this feature, in my opinion.
There will be a pointer to inventory but this is an id provided by the owning sub-system.
Why are we coming up with a different naming scheme than one we already have?  Shouldn't this be related to some kind of inventory item?
Removing this, it should be in the inventory
Is this related to something stored in phosphor-logging?
Yes the error log id added by the owning sub-system when creating the error
It doesn't look like you listed the types as requested in the previous patch set.
Why are these things tracked outside of Inventory?
Can we remove this section if it isn't ready?  It doesn't seem completely filled out.
What is this for? When will it be done?
"Library" as in shared library?  Why?  This is what dbus interfaces are for.
Please rename this file as 'guard-on-bmc.md' now to match style in the rest of the repository.
Do we have examples of these "multiple locations"?  If some are outside the control of the BMC how does the BMC know about them?  If they are all on the BMC, why are they in multiple locations?
for example the guard on the resources controlled by host is stored in a location which is accessible by both. A guard on fans or on a redundant BMC will be stored in BMC itself.
Are you saying more than two locations , or just two location BMC and Host?
We may have to support more than one locations

Can you elaborate this requirement. What is right GUARD repository mean , is it Host/BMC or some thing different?. Looking at the requirement  it will be good to look common area in BMC to store GUARD records for both BMC/Host.
The repository is a generic term for storing the GUARD records, this interface is not putting any restriction on the implementation of the specific GUARD implementation.
Is this rule applicable only for Host ?
Can we add an example here?  something like: "such as while the host is running for entities managed by the host".
This is not an assumption of this interface, so removing
Do we need to indicate when or why?  It isn't clear from these words why this would happen.

What specifically is an ID with respect to a "unit"?  Is this a inventory path or something else?

Below you've used Unit as a path.

In POWER processor all guardable parts modeled in inventory currently. The same key is going to use for deleting Guard records. Are you adding assumption, saying all guardble unit should be added in inventory?
All records which need to be presented to the user needs to be in the inventory.
You used 'unit' in create and 'device' in delete.  Does this have meaning for the difference?
I don't think you should call this an "Error" since that isn't what we call the thing you are talking about.  It is a Logging.Entry.

User.

Should we call this "Manual" since that is what we've referred to it elsewhere as?

We should run these terms past someone at Intel to see if we can come up with some commonality.  

It seems odd to use "Fatal"/"Critical" and "Predictive"/"Non-Critical" in our term vs definition.  Why not just use the right-hand side for everything?
I think you can strike these words to make it flow better
Is there a requirement that an external interface like Redfish or IPMI be able to view/create/delete guard entries? Redfish would be needed if we wanted to show these in the webui.
Yes, the external interfaces should be able to create/list/delete gard records.
An assumption that all guard records must have a corresponding phosphor-inventory object?
All the guardable units may not have an entry in the phosphor-inventory object. But the implementation should have an internal method to map the guard entry object to the original guard record.
Will this be a new application within openbmc or added to an existing one?
This should be a new application that provides a common interface for all types of guards
First mention of these. Be good to have a summary of these in the Background section.
Can you clarify this sentence a bit? I'm not understanding.
oh? So this will be similar to openpower-pels in phosphor-logging?
Adding a new type in the logging
I’ve asked the file to be renamed as ‘guard-on-bmc.md’, to follow other conventions, back on PS9 and was told “done”.  Still not done.
“taken care of _by_ the host”.  You inserted ‘of’ but removed ‘by’.
Is there a reason that “GUARD” is capitalized throughout this document as if it is an acronym?
will change that, it was like highlighting
Are these just examples? Because there are many more guardable units than just these two.
users can manually create guard on only these two, system can guard many more different types of units.
That doesn't come across at all so this will need to be reworded to clarify.
basically this document is for the guard interface to external users, so architecture specific details are not included.

Is this really how components like openpower-hw-diags will create a guard record? The inventory path will be able to specify processor chips and DIMMs, but we won't be able to do that for units within the chips like cores, buses, or memory channels.
There will be a com.ibm interface for the internal components to create the guard record, that part is not included in this document.

Why did “Unit” get added here and why are we keeping “human-readable” names?  How do you deal with translation?  Generally, we use enumerations and then have the user interface deal with turning it into something human readable.  In this case you already have a Path, so I don’t understand why you need another name and why it belongs in Guard if at all.

It looks like this was added in PS10, but I don’t see any discussion that would have instigated it in the code review.
The path will point to a FRU(or anything modeled in inventory), but if a unit inside the FRU, we may need a descriptive name to indicate that right?

I really hope not.  Adding arbitrary strings presents lots of problems for anyone trying to consume this property.  Were do the acceptable and possible values of this field get documented?  Translation at the external interface level is a huge issue, but it also tends to create tight-coupling between your code and some consumer and that coupling is often machine-specific (since only your machine will have sub-units A, B, and C).

If you have a sub-unit of a FRU (or device) that you want to perform guard on, my suggestion would be to add the sub-unit to the inventory model.  We do this already for processor cores, so why not any other unit?  If it is a unit specific to IBM or even a specific processor generation, put it in the `com.ibm` namespace.

Had discussions on this, here is the requirement 
- No requirement to manually guard a sub-unit of FRU which is not present in the inventory
- The only requirement is for displaying the system guarded information.
- The FRU containing the guard record is important for users since that is the replaceable unit.
- For an indication what is the type of the guarded unit can be displayed say memory controller.


I can change this 'Unit' to 'UnitType' which is a predefined information.
Alright.  But why do we even need UnitType when the object at Path already has this information?
Object at path is a FRU, but unit type an additional indication a sub unit is failed inside the FRU?

I’m still confused then.  I missed that you wrote “no requirement to _manually_ guard a sub-unit” but I guess that means you still want to be able to guard them.  Why aren’t they their own inventory items then?

You used “memory controller” as an example, but most of the Power chips have multiple memory controllers.  You’re going to need some way to indicate _which_ MC is guarded so that the right one is taken offline.  I think you need an inventory item to represent that entity.

There are two requirement 
1- Manually guard
2- Manipulate the list of guards

1 - Manually guard is only for the units visible in the inventory or visible to customers
2 - Manipulating guard list, usually guard is created for a system event and that guard record will get created in the backend. Such guard can be on some subunits in the chip, which cannot be replaced independently, my question was, when displaying such guard can we specify the FRU which is available in the inventory and a unit type to indicate what kind of unit failed inside the FRU. More information will be available from the error log pointed by the record.

> Such guard can be on some subunits in the chip, which cannot be replaced independently, my question was, when displaying such guard can we specify the FRU which is available in the inventory and a unit type to indicate what kind of unit failed inside the FRU. More information will be available from the error log pointed by the record.

Why aren't you creating inventory items for sub-units you want to have guard control over?  I know they can't be replaced independently, but that doesn't mean we can't put them into Inventory.  Inventory doesn't just cover FRUs.  We already have processor cores modeled.

The issue with the number of sub-units to  model all in the inventory, and updating its states during the boot. they are already modelled in the internal data structure for power system based applications to guard the subunits. We need only those units which can be guarded by user in this generic interface right?

> We need only those units which can be guarded by user in this generic interface right?

Isn't "list guard" going to return one of these structures?  I don't see how we can do anything programmatic with an arbitrary machine-specific string here.

> The issue with the number of sub-units to  model all in the inventory, and updating its states during the boot.

Why is quantity a problem?  It isn't obvious to me what the issue is.

Why do you need to update and maintain state?  What state are you talking about?  Inventory doesn't really have state.
The state(present/functional) of the core is updated during the boot, I think similarly we may need to update the state of other such sub-units too?
And the use case is only to show the type of the unit in the GUI, not the exact unit, so can we avoid modelling those if there is no other usecase?

How do you handle the case where there are two of the same sub-unit with a guard record?

Even if your *current* GUI use case requirements from your company are to show the sub-type, it doesn't seem like we should create a new method for describing that when we already have one: inventory objects.

Maybe the answer is for you to create a single inventory object to represent all of the sub-units of that type contained within the larger unit.  (Ex. memory controllers inside a processor)

- Basically it is an information what type sub unit is guarded with this guard record, so that can be handled.

- Creating a single object for all same type of sub-units under a FRU is doable. for example
Accelerator under processor
Memory controller under processor.

I'm not sure why we need Unit and Path.  Can you elaborate?  Why is guard responsible for figuring out the replacement unit?  Isn't it obvious from the Inventory hierarchy?  (How does guard figure this out other than by parsing the Inventory hierarchy anyhow?)
Yes that makes sense, the parent part can be found by the unit path
